body:
@vjagadish1989 
Rebased with master and fixed the merge conflicts.
Does increasing the timeout just mask the issues with all the connection and Kafka connection exceptions I see in the build log? Or are those expected?
For previous review comments, please refer to: https://github.com/apache/samza/pull/524
Adding @weisong44 @vjagadish1989 for review
@sborya Moved checkOffset into the if block.

@xinyuiscool @vjagadish1989 @prateekm 
Please take a look when you get a chance.
@vjagadish1989 Can you please take a look when you get a chance.

@vjagadish1989 @xinyuiscool 
Please take a look when you get a chance.
@cameronlee314 : If the remote branch is not deleted, I wonder if this PR can be resurrected? We should strive to complete review cycles in the same PR if possible.

Sounds good. I opened a new PR in this case because it was a significant change from the original, so the existing comments/discussions might not have been as valid. I will use the same PR in the future.
Makes sense! Thank you for clarifying.
@atoomula Is this still required? If not, please close this PR.
@cameronlee314 can you rebase from master and update this PR. @xinyuiscool can you please take a look at this.
@shanthoosh Minor: Please create a SAMZA ticket for this and move the details there. Lengthy descriptions aren't appropriate for commit messages. Thanks!

**Verification:**

```bash
[svenkata@svenkata-ld2 ~]$ cat ~/runTests-1.sh 
i=0
while [ $i -lt 151 ]; do
                i=`expr $i + 1`
                echo "Run " +$i 
                ./gradlew clean :samza-test:test -Dtest.single="TestZkLocalApplicationRunner" --debug --stacktrace >> ~/test-logs-runTests-1_23

done;
```

**Result:**
 
```bash
[svenkata@svenkata-ld2 ~]$ grep 'BUILD FAIL' test-logs-runTests-1_23 |wc -l
0
[svenkata@svenkata-ld2 ~]$ grep 'BUILD SUCCESS' test-logs-runTests-1_23 |wc -l
151
```

@prateekm 
I created a JIRA ticket before creating this PR, but forgot to link it with the PR. Thanks for pointing it out. Fixed.
cc @vjagadish1989 @xinyuiscool @sborya for review.
also, what do you think about editing this PR title to something on the lines of:  "Add a ListGauge metric type". IMO, It's more indicative of what its contents are.

@vjagadish1989 Checkstyle failure:
```
EventHubConfig.java:104: 'block rcurly' have incorrect indentation level 8, expected level should be 10.
```

Fix it and ship it.

Thanks for the patch. The idea is awesome. I actually think that we can be even more lazier: no start() function in the SystemAdmins(), and only do systemAdmin.start() when the getSysteAdmin() is called. That way we don't need to start the admin it if the system is not being used. This is actually the case in Beam: I configured the kafka system as default system for intermediate topics, but it's not being used in beam tests since we only have 1 task (no repartition needed). Now after upgrading to 0.14.1, I saw the kafka admin getting created and constantly logging warnings about broker not available. I would suggest keeping the old behavior and only create the admin when used.

SystemAdmins.getSystemAdmin() gets called throughout the lifecycle of the container (e.g. startup, commit). We are reusing SystemAdmin instances, so do we want to be calling SystemAdmin.start() every time someone wants a SystemAdmin? That seems a bit inconsistent with the normal start/stop usage pattern.
For the problem you are seeing in Beam: By the time Samza needs to instantiate the SystemAdmin instances, does Samza know if the default system will actually get used? Or is there some "runtime" usage of the default system that can't be detected at start time? If we can detect that the default system will never actually be used, we could avoid instantiating that system in the first place.

As discussed offline, created a separate pull requests for 
ListGauge metric type https://github.com/apache/samza/pull/541
and separate ones for SnapshotReporter improvement, and DiagnosticAppender integr with ListGauge.

I have a separate PR that shows how this abstraction is used for error-tracking.
https://github.com/apache/samza/pull/543

@rayman7718 : I meant that you don't need the interface and the corresponding implementations. I was proposing to inline the logic inside the `ListGauge` itself. We don't need the ability to schedule evictions asynchronously - we can instead trigger them when a new element is added.
merged and submitted, thanks much @apoorva121 for your contribution!
cc. @vjagadish1989 for review.
Completely removed evictionpolicy separation, merged all eviction logic into listgauge
I've updated the PR based on comments, can you kindly merge it?
tested manually.
@sborya what does this change? Github shows files changed == 0.
oops. Fixed. File should be in.
cc. @vjagadish1989 @nickpan47 @xinyuiscool @jmakes for review and feedback.

@rayman7718 : can we change the title to be something on the lines of:
"SAMZA-1234: Add  .."

Just bumping this a bit. I'm writing a Clojure API for Samza and this would be very helpful for testing the Samza-based implementation of the API. I wrote a separate implementation that uses common Clojure stuff (`core.async`, transducers, etc.) to mimic the flow of data through a Samza application because I wanted development and testing of Samza apps to be accessible, natural, and dependency-free. It would be nice to test the Samza-native implementation without needing direct access to a cluster.
merged and submitted. Thanks @rayman7718!
@prateekm for review

@vjagadish1989 @xinyuiscool 
Please take a look when you get a chance.
@prateekm : thanks for reviewing. I've addressed all of the feedback. take another pass at it when you get a chance?

**Verification:**

```bash
i=0
while [ $i -lt 150 ]; do
                i=`expr $i + 1`
                echo "Run " +$i 
                ./bin/integration-tests.sh /tmp/samza-tests/ standalone-integration-tests --nopassword >> ~/test-logs-runTests-1_26
done;
```

**Result:** 

```bash
grep -i 'passed' ~/test-logs-runTests-1_26 | wc -l 
750

grep -i 'failed' ~/test-logs-runTests-1_26 | wc -l 
0
```

Though the tests were run for 150 times, the result had 750 `passed` text since each test prints `passed` 5 times like the following:

```
2018-06-15 10:28:30,870 zopkio.test_runner [INFO] test_kill_leader----passed
2018-06-15 10:28:30,870 zopkio.test_runner [INFO] test_kill_multiple_followers----passed
2018-06-15 10:28:30,870 zopkio.test_runner [INFO] test_kill_leader_and_a_follower----passed
2018-06-15 10:28:30,870 zopkio.test_runner [INFO] test_kill_one_follower----passed
2018-06-15 10:28:30,871 zopkio.test_runner [INFO] test_pause_resume_leader----passed
```
@atoomula Can you fix the checkstyle failures (see the travis build results).

please create a jira and link it to the PR title: 
eg: SAMZA-1234: Refactor metrics for the table api

Created Jira
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SAMZA-1751
nit in PR title:  "SAMZA-1234: "
LGTM!

@xinyuiscool @vjagadish1989 @sborya 
Please take a look when you get a chance.
@cameronlee314 just curious whether you have run the local build for this PR? Both Jenkins and travis builds failed.
I thought I did, but I will try again. Maybe it needs a re-merge too.

@nickpan47 The Travis failure seems unrelated to this change. The changes in this PR don't seem related to the test that failed in Travis. The test that failed in Travis passes locally on linux and mac. The full build also succeeds locally on linux. Also, the most recent Jenkins build just passed.
Merged and submitted. Local build passed as well. Thanks!
@sborya for final review
It looks like there are more places where the lifecycle is not managed correctly, so this PR is not yet complete. I will leave this open, but it does not need a review for now.
merged, submitted thanks!

@vjagadish1989 
Can you please take a look at this PR. This has been  around here for a while.

Made the following changes: 
 - Depend directly on using java objects rather than log4j objects in appender (done)
 - Check if logger already attached, only than attach appender to root logger (done)
 - JobConfig for samza.diagnostics.enabled (done)
- SnapshotSerdeV2 to serialize Throwables with type and other relevant info for error tracking (done), with unit test.

 - Obtain/store an exception's context in appender 
1. Container-level context is already present in MetricsHeaders. 
2. Adding TaskContext to SamzaException didnt quite work because TaskContext doesn't apply to many components (like KafkaSysCons).
3. Instead, we use the MDC map associated with the exception. Context can then be added by the components to MDC map, e.g., topicName, espressoTableName, etc. LOg4j's LoggingEvent takes care of multi-threading and async-appender.

4. In cases, such as KafkaSysConsumer the poll is for a set of SSPs and the exception message (with the erroring topic name) is populated by KafkaConsumer (which Samza has no control over).
merged and submitted thanks!
@shanthoosh @bharathkk for review

@cameronlee314 This PR is not for open review. Sorry about not making that explicit. We have couple of ways of implementing side input stores and this was one of the illustration of the prototype.

We decided to drop this prototype and go with a separate class for side input storage manager. I will take a look at the comments and apply whatever is applicable to the new prototype.
Question: will support for table come in a separate PR?
@bharathkk Also, build is failing because of checkstyle issues.
+1 to Cameron's comments on StorageManagerUtil and SideInputStorageManager. I think I already fixed some of them in my PR earlier. Let's check if they got merged correctly.
@bharathkk Let's close this PR.
Another PR with https://github.com/apache/samza/pull/575/ has fixes for both byte and fixed types.

- Addressed the log4j dependency issue by using a config for the Appender class, this removes the use of log4j Logger from SamzaContainer
- For log4j2, verified with Pawas that the getappender and addAppender apis are consistent. 

- Addressed the other Metrics comments.
@prateekm please take a look
@cameronlee314 @shanthoosh What was the conclusion? Should this be merged?
@pdu-mn1 Is this PR still relevant? If not, can you please close it? Thanks!
This can be merged. Sorry for not following up on it earlier.

Some more details on this issue:
- Samza calls consumer.poll on the EventHubsSystemConsumer
- consumer.poll() throws a com.microsoft.azure.eventhubs.OperationCancelledException

The OperationCancelledException thrown from the consumer is actually thrown in a separate EventHub-receiver thread and exception state is set on the main-thread.

The stack from the EventHub-receiver thread:
```
2018/07/24 02:30:55.657 ERROR [EventHubSystemConsumer] [Thread-90] [k2-document-consumer-war] [] Received non transient exception from EH client for ssp: SystemStreamPartition [eventhub, k2-memberprofiletrimmed, 95]
com.microsoft.azure.eventhubs.OperationCancelledException: Operation cancelled as the underlying request-response link closed, errorContext[NS: wus2-li-prod-k2-eh.servicebus.windows.net, PATH: k2-memberprofiletrimmed/ConsumerGroups/k2_azureprod1_cg/Partitions/95, REFERENCE_ID: 4360dd_3d96_G0_1532398855144, PREFETCH_COUNT: 999, LINK_CREDIT: 100, PREFETCH_Q_LEN: 0]
	at com.microsoft.azure.eventhubs.impl.RequestResponseChannel$ResponseHandler.onClose(RequestResponseChannel.java:244)
	at org.apache.qpid.proton.reactor.impl.ReactorImpl.dispatch(ReactorImpl.java:326)
	at org.apache.qpid.proton.reactor.impl.ReactorImpl.process(ReactorImpl.java:293)
	at com.microsoft.azure.eventhubs.impl.MessagingFactory$RunReactor.run(MessagingFactory.java:480)
	at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1142)
	at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:617)
	at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:745)
```

It seems that the root-cause is that eventhubs marks the `OperationCancelledException` as "non-transient" and we bubble up the exception to Samza's event-loop, shutting it down. Additionally, It seems like catching the `TimeoutException` alone may not fix this right?
@nickpan47 Are you OK with merging this PR? The test failures on travis seem to be unrelated. My local build passes consistently.

- Added simple synchronization to make appender attachment thread safe (from constructor). 
- Added default value for appender class path in job config. 
- Adding error logging in samza-container for appender instantiation.

@lhaiesp 
Just curious. 

* If we retry on TimeoutException, then how are we certain that the previously held `EventHub` connections by old receiver had been closed. Is there a chance, if we add this retry then will it cause resource leak?
* Do we think it's fair to add bounded, configurable retries on `Exception` in receiver renewal?

Please share your thoughts.

@shanthoosh 

It's completely fair to give up if fail to shutdown the old resource. And that's how we implement it today. The reality is that there is no retry on samza standalone and no nurse job in K2 container. Every time anything happens a human being has to manually restart the service. 

There will be potentially resource leak so I will suggest the users alert on file handlers. 

I'm now going to implement a retry logic in the eventhubs consumer which recreates a new EH client if non-transient errors happen. This is a stop-gap solution, before nurse job is ready on azure.

@shanthoosh :
These are good points,
- Probably not worth adding separate retries for `TimeoutException`s thrown from `receiver#close` since we are not _yet_ sure if there are resource leaks. 
- Had a discussion with @lhaiesp and the plan is to add retries for non-transient errors instead of bubbling the exception back up to Samza.

Hope that clarifies!
@xinyuiscool please take a look
Simply fixing the timeout exception will not address the issue. Instead will implement retry logic on system consumer. Deprecate this PR and start a new one

@prateekm @xinyuiscool @sborya 
Please take a look when you get a chance.

@nickpan47 Definitely needs to be documented. The documentation will be part of the System/StreamDescriptor SEP and implementation. I'll also add it inline to the ExecutionPlanner with the StreamDescriptors PR.
cc @rayman7718, in case you have any feedback on the MetadataStore interface from the perspective of a diagnostics data store.

@bharathkk  @xinyuiscool 

Do we need to handle `EOS` envelopes in register, update methods as well? 

In register the comparator is invoked to see if  existingOffset for a SSP has to be replaced.

1. Here's a sample scenario. Let's say two tasks consume from the same SSP in a container. Let's assume one task is at EOS and other task is at beginning of the stream for that SSP. After a `SamzaContainer` bounce, they both could try to register with different offsets for the same SSP in `BootstrappingChooser`. So we could potentially run into not comparable scenario in `BootstrappingChooser.register` method as well.

2. It would be good to add unit tests to verify different EOS handling scenarios in BootstrappingChooser.
@shanthoosh : Would be preferable to structure the metadata store API to have string keys and byte-array values. Strings offer you nice properties around equality and prefix-checks.

@xinyuiscool @sborya 
Please take a look when you get a chance.

@fredji97 
I think after yi pan's serializable operator changes, `samza-hello-samza` repository does not build with `samza` open source head. I'm fixing the compilation problems in `samza-hello-samza`. Please update the PR with my fixes and then merge it.
@prateekm : could you please take a look?
cc. @nickpan47 @vjagadish1989 @xinyuiscool for review.
@vjagadish1989    Updated based on feedback. Also did some manual test through ITestEventHubSystemConsumer, the retry logic is working properly.

@rmatharu 
Can you update the PR with this JIRA: `SAMZA-1791`(created to fix the problem). It will be easier for the committers for fix with it.

@prateekm : I move the Files.move() out of the try{} block again since we should close the streams before we do the file movement. This is to enforce the write to the offset file before move. The IOExceptions are handled from the callers so we don't need to catch them in this function. The current handling of failing the container looks ok to me since it should happen very rarely, as we haven't seen it happening in production.

@xinyuiscool Makes sense to move this to its own try-catch block. It might still be better to handle IOException explicitly and revert to a normal move + replace existing. The IOException can happen if the implementation doesn't support replacing existing files as a part of the move. My concern is that this might fail on a particular platform consistently and we'll always end up rebootstrapping. Alternatively, if you've tested that it works on OSX and Linux, that'll be good enough for now.

Otherwise LGTM, feel free to merge this.
Good point on testing on both OSX and linux. I only tested on linux. Let me try OSX. Thanks.

@vjagadish1989  @prateekm  This does make sense. Though it's not really "minimal refactor". The offset management and some of the error handling logic need to be transferred from EH to BEM.  Can we de-prioritize for now? I'm still investigating the real root cause of this issue (despite that we add retry, we never know what was really going on) and I'm working on some problem with brooklin msft when upgrading to the newer samza version

@nickpan47 @weisong44 @xinyuiscool 

Please help review, thanks!
Can you create a JIRA and update the PR title?

Done. 

Addressed comments, and added test.
